repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Part 1 of #32729 

These APIs are already exposed by tree-sitter API, so this is just a
simple binding to expose them to Lua. Since they are pretty low-level
and not reversible, leave it mostly undocumented for now.

This also adds the pattern indices to the output of `:Inspect!` so that it's actually feasible to identify a given pattern and disable it.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -288,15 +288,19 @@ function M.get_captures_at_pos(bufnr, row, col)
 
     local iter = q:query():iter_captures(root, buf_highlighter.bufnr, row, row + 1)
 
-    for id, node, metadata in iter do
+    for id, node, metadata, match in iter do
       if M.is_in_node_range(node, row, col) then
         ---@diagnostic disable-next-line: invisible
         local capture = q._query.captures[id] -- name of the capture in the query
         if capture ~= nil then
-          table.insert(
-            matches,
-            { capture = capture, metadata = metadata, lang = tree:lang(), id = id }
-          )
+          local _, pattern_i = match:info()

@@ -417,6 +417,10 @@ TREESITTER
   code block fence lines vertically.
 • |vim.treesitter.language.inspect()| shows additional information, including
   parser version for ABI 15 parsers.
+• New |TSQuery:disable_pattern()| and |TSQuery:disable_capture()| to turn off

@@ -417,6 +417,10 @@ TREESITTER

+• New |TSQuery:disable_pattern()| and |TSQuery:disable_capture()| to turn off

+• |vim.treesitter.get_captures_at_pos()| now returns the `pattern_id` of the

comment_data.body: this code is 99% identical to the above, please factor out into a local function.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -911,5 +911,65 @@ void ui_refresh(void)
 
       eq({ 2, { 1, 1, 2, 2 } }, result)
     end)
+
+    it('supports disabling patterns', function()
+      insert([[
+        void foo(int x, int y);
+      ]])
+      local query = [[
+        ((identifier) @func
+          (#eq? @func "foo"))
+        ((identifier) @param
+          (#eq? @param "x"))
+        ((identifier) @param
+          (#eq? @param "y"))
+      ]]
+
+      local result = exec_lua(function()
+        local query0 = vim.treesitter.query.parse('c', query)
+        query0.query:disable_pattern(2)
+
+        local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(0, 'c')
+        local root = parser:parse()[1]:root()
+        local captures = {}
+        for id, _, _, match in query0:iter_captures(root, 0) do
+          local _, pattern = match:info()
+          captures[#captures + 1] = { id = id, pattern = pattern }
+        end
+        return captures
+      end)
+
+      eq({ { id = 1, pattern = 1 }, { id = 2, pattern = 3 } }, result)
+    end)
+
+    it('supports disabling captures', function()

comment_data.body:
Ah, I thought it might just fall back to highlighting if there weren't actual docs to link to and I only really added a `news.txt` entry since the check failed on my first push.

Currently it appears there is no documentation at all for `TSQuery` (although it's referenced in some docs), so I'm not sure what the best way to document these new methods would be – would I add a new class type in `query.lua`, or break out a new file in `runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/_meta` or something?

I guess this is related also to #26721 (exposing more of the `TS*` classes in documentation)?

Edit, also:
> A small example snippet would also go a long way.

Makes sense, I guess this would probably make the most sense as part of `lua-treesitter-query` docs?

+• New |TSQuery:disable_pattern()| and |TSQuery:disable_capture()| to turn off

comment_data.body:
(replying here for threading purposes)

> (Are the pattern ids stable?)

This is a good question and one I also had when I started implementing this... I haven't really found any specific documentation that indicates "stability" of these but from what I understand:

1. This pattern ID is really just an index, so given a query like `(foo) (bar) (baz)` you get IDs of `0`, `1`, `2`, respectively
	- Because nvim may concatenate queries together (e.g. `;extends`, `;inherits`), any changes in query file load order or similar mechanisms has the potential to change the indices
2. Pattern IDs are used in a number of public tree-sitter APIs (like `TSQueryMatch` and `ts_query_disable_pattern`), so I think they can probably be considered as stable as the rest of the API?

         ---@diagnostic disable-next-line: invisible
         local capture = q._query.captures[id] -- name of the capture in the query
         if capture ~= nil then

comment_data.body: Pushed an update which adds `TSQuery` docs to the `lua-treesitter-query` section; it didn't seem to make sense to follow exactly the format already used by `TSNode`/`TSTree` because they have their own sections and there is already a (non-generated) `TREESITTER QUERIES` section, but please let me know if you think it deserves its own section or any wording changes.

@@ -417,6 +417,10 @@ TREESITTER
   code block fence lines vertically.
 • |vim.treesitter.language.inspect()| shows additional information, including
   parser version for ABI 15 parsers.
+• New |TSQuery:disable_pattern()| and |TSQuery:disable_capture()| to turn off

@@ -427,6 +427,10 @@ TREESITTER
   code block fence lines vertically.
 • |vim.treesitter.language.inspect()| shows additional information, including
   parser version for ABI 15 parsers.
+• |TSQuery:disable_pattern()| and |TSQuery:disable_capture()| to turn off
+  a specific pattern or capture in a query.
+• |vim.treesitter.get_captures_at_pos()| returns the `pattern_id` of the
+  pattern used to match each capture.

@@ -1514,6 +1536,56 @@ set({lang}, {query_name}, {text})                 *vim.treesitter.query.set()*
       • {text}        (`string`) Query text (unparsed).
 
 
+
+
+*TSQuery*
+    Extends: |userdata|
+
+    Reference to an object held by the treesitter library that is used as a
+    component of the |vim.treesitter.Query| for language feature support. See
+    |treesitter-query| for more about queries or
+    |vim.treesitter.query.parse()| for an example of how to obtain a query
+    object.
+
+    Fields: ~
+      • {disable_capture}  (`fun(self: TSQuery, capture_name: string)`) See
+                           |TSQuery:disable_capture()|.
+      • {disable_pattern}  (`fun(self: TSQuery, pattern_index: integer)`) See
+                           |TSQuery:disable_pattern()|.
+
+
+TSQuery:disable_capture({capture_name})            *TSQuery:disable_capture()*
+    Disable a specific capture in this query; once disabled the capture cannot
+    be re-enabled. {capture_name} should not include a leading "@".
+
+    Example: To disable the `@variable.parameter` capture from the vimdoc
+    highlights query: >lua
+        local query = vim.treesitter.query.get('vimdoc', 'highlights')
+        query.query:disable_capture("variable.parameter")
+        vim.treesitter.get_parser():parse()
+<
+
+    Parameters: ~
+      • {capture_name}  (`string`)
+
+TSQuery:disable_pattern({pattern_index})           *TSQuery:disable_pattern()*
+    Disable a specific pattern in this query; once disabled the pattern cannot
+    be re-enabled. The {pattern_index} for a particular match can be obtained
+    with |:Inspect!|, or by reading the source of the query (i.e. from
+    |vim.treesitter.query.get_files()|).
+
+    Example: To disable `|` links in vimdoc but keep other `@markup.link`s
+    highlighted: >lua

comment_regular_data.body: I think the exposed functions _should_ be documented, especially if you link them from `news.txt`. A small example snippet would also go a long way. (Are the pattern ids stable?)

title: feat(treesitter): disable captures and patterns on TSQuery
